awd_titl_txt: The Definition, Acquisition, and Fracture of Land Rights
awd_abstract_narration:
The explosion in American oil-and-gas production, made possible by "fracking" technologies and high prices, has drawn significant attention to government regulation. There is also an enormous private-law side of the energy boom. Property rights -- both to the land (surface rights) and to the oil and gas underneath (mineral rights)-- are required to get oil and gas from the underground to markets. This project studies how the industry acquires property rights in the oil-and-gas booming (and busting) states of North Dakota, Wyoming, and Montana. These rights are extremely fractured, so land acquisition needed to install a single well or pipeline can involve hundreds or thousands of individuals, companies, and governments. 

The focus of this research is on the people who make deals to lease and buy property, and compensate for damages: "landmen," brokers paid by energy companies; mineral and surface owners and renters; and attorneys. This project will use ethnographic observation and interviews, supplemented by archival and quantitative analysis, to find out how brokers, mineral and surface owners, and third parties
secure or prevent property deals (mineral leases, mineral sales, and right-of-way and other surface agreements), how they define fairness, and how they attempt to change the rules to accommodate these transactions.

por.por_cntn:
With the support of this award, Dr. Becher completed the research and most of the writing for a book manuscript, tentatively titled A Fractured Nation. Dr. Becher drafted approximately 85 percent of the book manuscript and secured an advanced contract with Oxford University Press. The award supported the writing of this manuscript and the completion of data collection, organization, and analysis for the research to be presented in the book. The award also supported public presentations that helped Becher publicize and refine her findings: Dr. Becher shared results at 18 national and international conferences and six individual presentations to academic departments in the US. In addition, the award allowed Dr. Becher to employ and mentor one undergraduate and two graduate students as research assistants. Also, during the award period, Dr. Becher completed a chapter about the project to be published in an international edited handbook on property and society; she initiated a teaching experiment connecting rural and urban university students; and she convened prominent rural sociologists to discuss the reception of rural studies within the broader discipline of sociology. (Unfortunately, COVID-related family care and teaching responsibilities slightly reduced the outcomes possible to achieve during this award.)

It is significant that information about the oil and gas industry’s dealings with property owners is coming from an independent and trusted source, and from rigorous research. Much of the public information about oil is authored by advocates promoting or condemning the oil industry, or by journalists who are more politically independent but focus on sensational stories rather than more mundane, everyday experiences.

This research will educate the public about the interests of oil companies and land and mineral owners, about the powers and limitations that both sides face in negotiations, and about what those involved consider best practices of land professionals, land owners, and energy companies. Public education about what leads to perceptions of fair deals promises to impact owner-landman interactions. In addition, a public with greater knowledge about the real, lived experience with property involved in oil development will be better prepared to craft and support legislation and administrative regulations that effectively lead to desired goals, such as equity, fairness, and economic development.

The production of oil and gas promises to create continued political contestation in the US, and this project will help inform attitudes and debates. Other social scientists are studying interactions and attitudes about public regulation as well as health, environmental, and economic consequences. But, with a few exceptions. they have largely ignored the importance of private law in oil production, and if they have studied it, they considered it wholly ineffective in enforcing public will. This project not only directs attention to private property but also demonstrates how private-property laws and customs might help accomplish public ideals.

With this project, Becher expands thinking about private property beyond existing work: Becher is adding substantive knowledge and developing theory about the importance of private property to American life. Although oil and gas are being debated in the news and in legislatures, and experienced by some on a very visceral level, most Americans know very little about the property rights and rules involved in oi-and-gas development. Becher forcibly argues that the distribution of private-property rights, private-property laws, and customary practices related to property all matter greatly to social outcomes. More specifically, the research exposes academics and other members of the public to the experiences of residents of oil-rich areas and to oil-industry-workers, to rural life in the Great Plains, to industrial farming and ranching, to the oil industry, and to property rights to the surface and underground.

With this project, Becher demonstrates the overlooked significance of private property in shaping culture, politics, and economics. She articulates and illustrates three complexities of how private property matters: (1) how private property shapes social identities; (2) how transactions that split and concentrate property holdings cement local political economic histories and power differences; and (3) how formal private-property laws and everyday actions establish social standards for human action affecting the land and the underground. These arguments will particularly resonate with economic sociologists and with multi-disciplinary scholars of law and society. More generally, this work promises to spark new public debates about how property matters to how Americans understand themselves, to how we use property to exert power, to how history has shaped those understandings and powers, and to how collective standards our interactions with land are established and enforced.
